fields.descriptive_line: Portrait miniature of an unknown woman, watercolour on vellum in imitation of John Hoskins, ca. 19th century.

fields.name: Special Exhibition of Portrait Miniatures on Loan at the South Kensington Museum

fields.physical_description:
Portrait, head and shoulders, to front and wearing a high collar, necklace and pendant.  Features in stippled brown and sanguine with blue shadowing and blue in the eyes; no carnation ground; hair in brown stippled over a light wash, washed over with gum; flowers in opaque yellow, red, green and white; dress in thin grey wash with orange for the pattern, white and gold details; dark grey with black detail for the band and chain; ruff and lace in white, the pearls in dark grey and white; background a blue wash; a gold marginal strip; on vellum put down on pasteboard.    
 
<u>Frame:</u>  Rectangular  ebony veneer over oak, with a gold slip; a card stuck to the backboard.
fields.title: Unknown Woman
fields.materials_techniques: Watercolour on vellum put down on pasteboard
fields.marks:
'IH'
 'Mary Countess of Pembroke/ Wife of Earl [William] Sister of Philip Sydney / by John Hoskins. / Strawberry Hill'
fields.exhibition_history: Special Exhibition of Portrait Miniatures on Loan at the South Kensington Museum (South Kensington Museum 01/01/1865-31/12/1865)
fields.bibliography: Murdoch, John. Seventeenth-century English Miniatures in the Collection of the Victoria & Albert Museum, London: The Stationery Office in association with the Victoria & Albert Museum, 1997. Cat. 40, pp.78-79. Full Citation: "40 Unknown Woman pseudo 1620 617-1882 Oval 57 x 50mm Features in stippled brown and sanguine with blue shadowing and blue in the eyes; no carnation ground; hair in brown stippled over a light wash, washed over with gum; flowers in opaque yellow, red, green and white; dress in thin grey wash with orange for the pattern, white and gold details; dark grey with black detail for the band and chain; ruff and lace in white, the pearls in dark grey and white; background a blue wash; a gold marginal strip; on vellum put down on pasteboard. Condition: Zinc-white retouches in the ruff; the pearls imitate the effect of blackened lead-white. Signed: Falsely, in gold, lower right: IH. Frame: Rectangular ebony veneer over oak, with a gold slip; a card stuck to the backboard inscribed by a nineteenth-century hand in ink: Mary Countess of Pembroke/ Wife of Earl [William] Sister of Philip Sydney / by John Hoskins. / Strawberry Hill. Provenance: Presumably Margaret, Duchess of Portland (born Cavendish, wife of William, 2nd Duke), by whom given to Horace Walpole; Strawberry Hill sale, 6 May 1842 (eleventh day), lot 47 'a present from the Duchess of Portland, a perfect gem' , bt JP Bevan, 27 gns; by 1865 John Jones. by whom bequeathed to the Museum, 1882. Exhibited: South Kensington 1865, no. 894. Literature: Foster 1903, vol. n, p. 79; Goulding 1914-15, p. 38; Foster 1914-16, vol. n. p. 140, no. 144 (see also no. 143); Long 1923, p. 82; Long 1930, p. 37; Summary Catalogue, 1981, p. 31 (late copy after). The early provenance of this subject would argue for a date in the eighteenth century, but the technique, with its elaborate imitation of the effect of blackened lead-white or silver, and its gummed passages, would otherwise suggest that the miniature is an 'antiquarian' copy of the early nineteenth century. This is supported by Avril Hart's observation (1) that the structure of the dress, particularly at the junction of sleeves and bodice, appears to have been misunderstood, and that the standing ruff is not correctly placed. Although Foster recognised the poor quality of the miniature, Goulding was the first to dismiss both attribution and identification. He regarded a version in the collection of the Dukes of Rutland at Belvoir Castle, called Frances Cecil, Countess of Cumberland, as the original, and the Beauchamp and the Jones Collection examples (both called Mary Sidney) as replicas of it. Long (2) discussed the rival identifications, preferring Frances Cecil, and in 1930 definitively rejected Mary Sidney. On the other hand, he evidently disagreed with Goulding that the Beauchamp version was a copy of the Belvoir, and listed it in British Miniaturists (3) as autograph. Meanwhile, the Beauchamp Collection had been on loan at the V&A, where the label claimed that the miniature was 'much like' the so-called Catherine Knevet, Countess of Suffolk in the Buccleuch Collection, which Long, again in British Miniaturists. listed also as autograph and which he nowhere else considered as comparable with the Beauchamp/Belvoir/Jones group. Of the sitters thus suggested for a portrait of c.16 2 0, Mary Sidney (1561-1621) is clearly impossible; Catherine Knevet (who was already a widow in 1583 when she married the Earl of Suffolk, b.1561) is unlikely, and Frances Cecil (1594 ?-1644) is at least possible. It is not possible to go further, unless to say that this miniature, sharing an impossible identification with the finer Beauchamp miniature, presumably derives from it. 1 Personal communication, 1993. 2 Long 1923, p. 82. 3 Long 1929, p. 226 . 4 Ibid."
fields.history_note: <u>Provenance:</u> Presumably Margaret, Duchess of Portland (born Cavendish, wife of William, 2nd Duke), by whom given to Horace Walpole; Strawberry Hill sale, 6 May 1842 (eleventh day), lot 47  'a present from the Duchess of Portland, a perfect gem' , bt JP Bevan, 27 gns; by 1865 John Jones. by whom bequeathed to the Museum, 1882.
